channel.title: Moritz College of Law Latest News
channel.description: The latest news from the Ohio State University Moritz College of Law

item.title: JDR Symposium to Address Disputed Election Processes
item.description: Although Bush v. Gore and, more recently, Coleman v. Franken, made apparent the problems associated with judicial resolution of disputed elections, procedures for unraveling electoral disagreements remain uncertain and time consuming at both state and federal levels. On Feb. 18, the Ohio State Journal on Dispute Resolution will host a symposium entitled: “Talking the Vote: Facility Disputed Election Processes through ADR.” This symposium will examine the methods currently used to resolve electoral disputes, as well as the possibility of incorporating alternative dispute resolution techniques to overcome their limitations.

item.title: Moritz Launches Innovative Corporate Fellowship Program
item.description: The Ohio State University Moritz College of Law proudly announces the launch of the Moritz Corporate Fellowship Program, an innovative initiative that places new Moritz graduates within the general counsel offices of leading national corporations. The fellowships, which follow the judicial clerkship model, will match the specific needs of each corporate partner while putting recent graduates’ top-flight training and ability to immediate use inside the legal departments of major companies.

item.title: Dan Shaban '82 Wins 2nd Annual Alumni Face Off
item.description: Congratulations to Dan Shaban '82 for emerging from a three-way tie and winning the 2nd Annual Alumni Face Off college football picks. Shaban, a Connecticut Superior Court judge in Middlebury, Conn., chose Ohio State in the Sugar Bowl with a combined score of 51 points (just six points off the actual total of 57). Thanks to all for participating and we look forward to the challenge again next year!

item.title: Leadership Program Thriving in Fourth Year
item.description: Moritz is distinctive among the country’s leading law schools for many reasons and in many different ways. One of those is our commitment to leadership development. At Moritz, we are deeply committed to teaching students how to be outstanding lawyers, while also seeking to instill the values of public service and leadership.

item.title: Yvette McGee Brown '85 Appointed to Ohio Supreme Court
item.description: Today Yvette McGee Brown ’85 was appointed to a vacancy on the Supreme Court of Ohio and will assume the position Jan. 1. McGee Brown, a former Franklin County judge, will be the first African-American woman to serve on the Ohio Supreme Court, according to The Columbus Dispatch.

item.title: Fall Hooding Ceremony Honors Eight Graduates
item.description: On Friday, Dec. 10, eight Moritz College of Law students will graduate in the College’s Fall Hooding Ceremony. The ceremony will begin at 4 p.m. in the College’s Saxbe Auditorium in Drinko Hall, 55 W. 12th Ave. A small reception will follow in Lou’s Café, also in Drinko Hall.

item.title: Read the December Issue of SideBar
item.description: The December issue of SideBar, the monthly alumni e-newsletter, is now available.  Read it today!

item.title: Apply Now for the 2011 Summer in Oxford Program
item.description: For the 25th consecutive year, the Ohio State Moritz College of Law and the University of Oxford will offer their Summer Law Program at the University of Oxford in Oxford, England. The program, which is one of the oldest overseas law programs in existence, is scheduled for July 4, 2011 to Aug. 7, 2011. The program is limited to 60 participants.

item.title: Vince Brockman '88 to Compete in Sixth Ironman Triathlon
item.description: Vince Brockman ’88, the head of the legal department at Scotts Miracle-Gro, will compete this month in his sixth Ironman Triathlon. “Finding a wholesome release for that stress is key for me,” he said. Brockman chose exercise, but he has taken his efforts to an entirely new level.

item.title: Prof. Alexander Named in The Root 100
item.description: Moritz Professor Michelle Alexander was included in “The Root 100,” a list of “young African-American pace setters and game changers” compiled by The Root, a prominent daily online magazine devoted to providing commentary from black perspectives.
